solution.text:
height of the upper half(smaller cone)= \(\frac {_{{6*j}}_}2=_{{3*j}}_\)
let the radius of this cone be r
The volume of the cone = \(\frac 13 \times \pi \times r^2 \times _{{3*j}}_\)
It is given that the upper half is remelted to a cylinder
so, Volume of the cylinder = volume of the upper cone
\(\pi \times _{k}_^2 \times _{j}_= \frac 13 \times \pi \times r^2 \times _{{3*j}}_\)
\(\Rightarrow r=_{k}_\)
Now we have the radius of the base of cone = radius of the top face of the frustum
let the radius of the base of the frustum be R
By similarity of the sections of smaller and bigger cones we can say that
\(\frac {_{{6*j}}_}{R}=\frac {_{{3*j}}_}{_{k}_}\)
\(\Rightarrow R=_{{2*k}}_\)
Volume of a frustum of a cone is \(\frac {\pi}3 \times H \times [r^2 + R^2 + rR] \)
putting the values, H=_{{3*j}}_,r=_{k}_,R=_{{2*k}}_
we get,\(\frac {22}{7\times 3} \times _{{3*j}}_ \times [_{k}_^2 + _{{2*k}}_^2 + _{{2*k*k}}_] \)
\(\Rightarrow _{{trunc(pi_val*j*(k*k+4*k*k+2*k*k),2)}}_\)

content.text:
If a cone of height _{{6*j}}_ cm is cut into two parts at the middle of the height parallel to the base.
The upper conical part is melted and converted into a cylinder of radius _{k}_cm and height _{j}_ cm.
Find the volume of the bottom frustum of the cone.
